caption: A hand points to a blue circular screen displaying "SOFTWARE TESTING" with eight interconnected icons, including a laptop, brain, lightbulb, microphone, gears, and graph..  The image shows a person's hand pointing at a screen displaying the word "SOFTWARE TESTING" in a circular frame. The hand is positioned near the center of the screen, with the fingers extended towards the screen. The background of the image is dark blue with a technological theme, featuring various icons and symbols related to software testing and technology. These icons include a laptop, a person with a headset, a lightbulb, a circuit board, a brain, gears, and a graph. The overall scene suggests a focus on software testing and technology.

The "module5" logo, featuring a purple rectangle with white text, is displayed against a white background..  The image features a purple rectangular sign with the text "module5" prominently displayed in white letters. The sign is positioned against a white background, making the purple color stand out.

A blue collared shirt with 2 sleeves, size L, blue buttons, and a date-like appearance is shown, accompanied by a list of questions for verification..  The image presents a blue dress shirt with a collar, long sleeves, and buttons. It is shown in a folded state, and the shirt appears to be made of a cotton fabric. The shirt is displayed against a white background, and there are five questions posed to the viewer, each asking about the shirt's attributes. The questions include: "2 sleeves?", "Is it size L?", "Is it blue?", "Are any buttons missing?", "Does it fit?", "Is it comfortable to drive in?", "Does the colour match my eyes?", "Can I afford it?", "Is it good quality?", and "Will my date like it?".

A cartoon man in a white shirt and blue tie evaluates software products, with a checklist of verification and validation techniques..  A cartoon man in a suit and tie, a computer monitor, and a checklist

A spiral diagram illustrates the stages of System Testing, Validation testing, Integration testing, Unit testing, Code, Design, Requirements, and System engineering..  The image presents a spiral diagram illustrating the process of System Testing. The spiral is divided into concentric layers, each representing a different stage of the testing process. The outermost layer is labeled "System engineering," indicating the initial phase of the testing process. The layers inside the spiral include "Design Requirements," "Code," "Unit testing," "Integration testing," "Validation testing," "System testing," and "System engineering." A line is drawn through the center of the spiral, representing the flow of the testing process.

A software testing hierarchy, divided into Manual Testing, Automation Testing, Functional Testing, Non-Functional Testing, System Testing, Performance Testing, Usability Testing, Compatibility Testing, Incremental Testing, Non-Incremental Testing, Load Testing, Stress Testing, Scalability Testing, Stability Testing, and Bottom-up Testing..  The image presents a hierarchical structure of software testing types, categorized into Manual Testing, Automation Testing, Functional Testing, Non-Functional Testing, System Testing, Performance Testing, Usability Testing, Compatibility Testing, Load Testing, Stress Testing, Scalability Testing, Stability Testing, Incremental Testing, Non-Incremental Testing, Top-down Testing, Bottom-up Testing, White Box, Black Box, Grey Box, Integration Testing, System Testing, Performance Testing, Usability Testing, Compatibility Testing, Load Testing, Stress Testing, Scalability Testing, Stability Testing

A feedback loop connects a developer to a tester or developer, with a laptop displaying code and a magnifying glass for review..  The image shows a feedback loop between a developer and a tester or developer. The developer is shown with a laptop, while the tester is represented by a magnifying glass. The feedback loop indicates that the developer has written code and requested a review. The tester then reviews the code and provides feedback. The feedback loop is visually represented by arrows connecting the developer to the tester.

Three boxes labeled "Black Box Testing", "White Box Testing", and "Grey Box Testing" are shown with a plus sign, indicating internal functionality is unknown..  The image presents a visual representation of three different testing methods: Black Box Testing, White Box Testing, and Grey Box Testing. Each method is represented by a box, with the boxes being colored and labeled accordingly.

The Black Box Testing method is shown with a dark blue box, indicating that the internal functionality is unknown. The White Box Testing method is represented with a white box, indicating that internal functionality is known. The Grey Box Testing method is shown with a grey box, indicating that internal functionality is partially known.

The boxes are placed next to each other, with the addition of a plus sign (+) symbol between them, symbolizing the sum of the three testing methods. The text "Internal functionality is unknown" is present at the bottom of the image, providing context for each testing method.

Three diamond-shaped boxes labeled "White box Testing," "Black box Testing," and "Gray box Testing" are arranged in a triangular formation, each with a unique color and text..  The image presents a visual representation of the three types of manual testing: White box testing, Black box testing, and Gray box testing. Each type of testing is represented by a diamond-shaped shape, with the colors green, orange, and blue used to differentiate them. The text "Types of Manual Testing" is displayed at the top of the image, clearly indicating the subject matter.

A blue cube labeled "Application Code" with a network diagram and two pink speech bubbles labeled "Test Case Input" and "Test Case Output" is shown..  The image shows a blue box labeled "Application Code" with a flowchart diagram on its front. The flowchart includes a series of interconnected boxes, each representing a different step or process in the application code. There are also two speech bubbles, one labeled "Test Case Input" and the other labeled "Test Case Output." The flowchart visually represents the flow of the application code, highlighting the sequence of steps and their dependencies.

A black cardboard box with a white label and a black stripe is shown against a white background, accompanied by the text "Black box - we do not know anything.".  The image shows a black box with a white label on it. The box is sitting on a white surface, and there is a shadow cast by the box. The text "Black box â€“ we do not know anything" is written in black at the bottom of the image.
The QA tester logo, featuring the letters "QA" in black against a white background, is centered and bold..  The image contains the text "QA testers" in a sans-serif font.

A black cube labeled "Black Box Testing" is surrounded by a person with question marks, indicating a testing process..  The image presents a diagram illustrating the Black Box Testing process. A person is shown with question marks above their head, suggesting confusion or uncertainty. The person is standing in front of a black box, which is labeled "Black Box Testing." The diagram also includes an arrow pointing to the left, labeled "Input," and an arrow pointing to the right, labeled "Output." This visual representation highlights the input and output stages of the testing process.

A mobile number entry form displays a light blue box for entering a ten-digit mobile number, with "Enter Mobile Number" and "Submit" buttons..  The image shows a mobile number entry form with a purple background. The form has a light blue box at the top, which says "Enter Mobile Number." Below this box, there are two buttons: one labeled "Submit" and the other labeled "Back." The buttons are positioned on either side of the central box, indicating that the user can either enter their mobile number or submit the form.

A table displays the results of a test case, categorizing it as invalid (digits >-11), invalid (digits <-9), valid (digits =-10), and valid (digits =-10)..  The image shows a table with four columns labeled "INVALID," "INVALID," "VALID," and "VALID." Each column represents a different number of test cases: 1, 2, 3, and 4. The table displays the number of test cases for each invalid case: 9384726219, 984543985, 9991456234, and 9893451483. The "INVALID" column shows that there are more than 9 test cases for each invalid case.

A timeline shows the progression of a project, from "Invalid partition" to "Valid partition" with a 30% completion rate, $578, $140, $370, and $530 milestones..  The image presents a timeline of four stages of a process, each labeled with a stage number and corresponding dollar amounts. The stages are labeled as "Invalid partition," "Valid partition (10%)," "Valid partition (20%)," and "Valid partition (30%)." The stages are separated by a black line, and the dollar amounts are represented by red boxes. The stages are $578, $140, $370, and $530, respectively.

An orange line labeled "a" connects two orange circles labeled "x(min)" and "x(max)", with an arrow labeled "b" pointing to the right..  The image shows a line graph with two labeled points, labeled "a" and "b." The line graph has an orange circle at the beginning, and a yellow arrow pointing to the right labeled "x." The graph has three labeled points: "x(min)," "x(nom)," and "x(max+)," with arrows indicating the direction of the line. The graph is labeled "a" and "b," suggesting a comparison or relationship between the two points.

A table displays the results of three password conditions: Email (condition1), Password (condition2), and Expected Result (Action)..  The image contains a table with three columns: Email (condition1), Password (condition2), and Expected Result (Action). Each column has a T for True, F for False, and F for Incorrect email. The table shows that all three conditions are True for Email (condition1), False for Password (condition2), and Incorrect email for Expected Result (Action).

A transition diagram illustrates a state change process, with input and output states, an event, and a transition arrow indicating a change from State 1 to State 2..  The image shows a flowchart illustrating a transition process between two states. The transition is represented by an arrow, indicating a change from State 1 to State 2. The flowchart includes two states, State 1 and State 2, with an input and output. The input is represented by a rectangle, and the output is represented by an oval. The transition process is labeled as "Transition," and the diagram is titled "Transition."

A process diagram illustrates a sequence of events: incorrect PIN, incorrect attempt, incorrect attempt, and successful attempt, leading to account locked..  The image shows a flowchart illustrating the process of unlocking an account. It has three main sections: Start, Attempt Failed, and Success. The Start section shows a pin being inserted, and the Attempt Failed section shows a failed attempt with a wrong pin. The Success section shows a successful attempt with a correct pin. The Account Locked section indicates that the account has been successfully unlocked.

A login screen with a welcome screen and error message flow to a login screen with a login screen and error message flow, leading to a login screen with a login screen and error message flow..  The image shows a flowchart illustrating the login process. It consists of three states: State 1 (Login Screen), State 2 (Logout), and State 3 (Error Message). The login screen is represented by a blue rectangle labeled "Login Screen," and the login process involves entering credentials. The error message is displayed in a blue rectangle labeled "Error Message." The login screen and the login process are connected to the error message, indicating that the login process may fail due to an error.

A 3x3 grid displays twelve squares, each representing a different quality: Security, Availability, Efficiency, Integrity, Reliability, Survivability, Usability, Flexibility, Scalability, Reusability, Interoperability, and Portability..  The image presents a grid of twelve squares, each containing a different characteristic or quality. The squares are arranged in a 4x3 grid, with each row representing a different quality: Security, Availability, Efficiency, Integrity, Reliability, Survivability, Usability, Flexibility, Scalability, Reusability, Interoperability, and Portability.

A 3D diagram illustrates the levels of testing, from Unit Testing to System Testing, with acceptance testing at level 4..  The image presents a step-by-step process of levels of testing, labeled as 1, 2, 3, and 4. It shows a progression from unit testing to acceptance testing, with each level building upon the previous one. The steps are visually represented as a stepped pyramid shape, with each level distinctively colored. The color-coded steps help to differentiate between the stages and facilitate understanding of the testing process.

A pyramid-shaped diagram illustrates the stages of software development, from acceptance testing to end user testing, with integration testing and end user testing at the top..  The image presents a pyramid-shaped diagram illustrating the different stages of software testing. The pyramid is divided into four levels, each representing a specific testing stage: Acceptance Testing, System Testing, Integration Testing, and End User Testing.

The pyramid is divided into four sections, each representing a different testing stage. The topmost section is labeled "Acceptance Testing," indicating the final stage before the software is released to the end user. The bottom section is labeled "End User Testing," signifying the final testing phase before the software is deployed to the end-users.

The diagram also includes icons representing testers and end users, indicating the roles and responsibilities of each stage. The testers are shown in blue, while the end users are shown in gray. Arrows connect the stages, indicating the flow of testing process.

Three blue spheres labeled "Module A", "Module B", and "Module C" are arranged in a triangular formation, with "Module A" and "Module B" under "Tested in Unit Testing" and "Module C" under "Under Integration Testing"..  The image presents a visual representation of integration testing, specifically focusing on modules A, B, and C. There are three large, glossy, circular balls representing the modules, with each module labeled as "Module A," "Module B," and "Module C." The balls are arranged in a triangular formation, with Module A positioned at the top left, Module B in the middle, and Module C at the bottom right.

The text "Tested in Unit Testing" is written above the balls, indicating the purpose of the testing process. The phrase "Under Integration Testing" is written below the balls, emphasizing the stage of the testing process. The overall design is clear and visually appealing, making it easy to understand the different stages of integration testing.

A green flowchart illustrates a software development process, from setup to execution, with stages labeled "Setup Test Environment," "Generate Test Cases," "Generate Testing Data," "Execute Test Cases," "Execute Test Data," "Log Defects," "Regression Testing," and "Defect Reporting.".  The image shows a flowchart illustrating the process of setting up a test environment, generating test cases, executing test cases, and reporting defects. The flowchart is divided into eight distinct sections, each representing a different step in the process. The sections are labeled as Setup Test Environment, Generate Test Cases, Generate Testing Data, Execute Test Cases, Execute Test Cases Data, Regression Testing, Defect Reporting. The flowchart visually represents the sequence of steps involved in the testing process, highlighting the importance of each step in ensuring the quality and reliability of the software being tested.

A software acceptance test results in a failed acceptance test, causing a software application to be rejected and a product not ready for customer use..  The image shows a software acceptance test process. It depicts a person testing software applications, with a red explosion-shaped cloud labeled "Acceptance Test" indicating that the software application has been accepted. There are three boxes: one labeled "Software Application," one labeled "Software Application Passed," and one labeled "Software Application Failed."

The person testing the software is represented by a person icon, and the software application boxes are labeled with "Software Application" and "Software Application Passed." The "Software Application Failed" box is marked with a red "X," indicating a failure. The "Product Ready for Customer's Use" box is marked with a green checkmark, indicating that the software application is ready for customer use.

A software development lifecycle process, from Unit Testing to User Acceptance Testing, with QA Team and End-users, is depicted in a flowchart..  The image displays a flowchart illustrating the process of unit testing, integration testing, system testing, user acceptance testing, and UAT sign-off. It shows the sequence of steps, from Unit Testing to Production Rollout, with end-users and QA Team members involved. The flowchart highlights the collaboration between Dev Team and QA Team to ensure the quality of the software.

A person types on a laptop, with a plant, coffee cup, and tools in the background, transitioning to a software result with a computer monitor and person..  The image shows a flowchart illustrating the process of creating a software project. The flowchart is divided into three sections: Tools, Framework, and Software.

In the Tools section, there is a person working on a laptop, indicating the development of the software project. The Framework section shows a laptop with a screen displaying a software development environment, suggesting the use of software tools and frameworks.

In the Software section, there is a computer monitor with a person working on it, indicating the development of the software project. The Software section also includes a laptop, a mouse, and a cup, representing the tools and software used in the development process.

The Result section shows a computer monitor with a person working on it, indicating the successful completion of the software project. The person in the Software section is wearing a red shirt, suggesting a positive outcome or completion of the project.

A flowchart illustrates the stages of regression testing, including Retest, Regression, Prioritization, and All, with a recycling symbol and checkmarks for each stage..  The image presents a flowchart illustrating the process of regression testing. It is divided into three sections: Retest All, Regression Test Selection, and Prioritization of Test Cases.

In the Retest All section, there is a recycling symbol (green triangle) and a checkmark (green checkmark) next to a set of four checkboxes. These checkboxes represent different stages of the testing process.

The Regression Test Selection section shows a flowchart with a flowchart head, a flowchart body, and a flowchart footer. This section highlights the steps involved in selecting the right regression model, including data collection, model selection, and model evaluation.

The Prioritization of Test Cases section features a flowchart with a flowchart head, a flowchart body, and a flowchart footer. This section illustrates the process of prioritizing test cases based on their importance, complexity, and potential impact on the outcome.

A flowchart illustrates the three types of regression testing: Unit Regression, Regional Regression, and Full Regression..  The image presents a visual representation of three types of regression testing: Unit Regression, Regional Regression, and Full Regression. Each type of regression testing is represented by a separate colored circle, with the circles arranged in a descending order of complexity. The circles are labeled with the type of regression testing, and the text above them clearly states the type of regression testing. The circles are positioned against a black background, creating a visually distinct and organized presentation of the three types of regression testing.

A dark blue window displays a white box with "Search field(1-35 characters)" and two buttons: "SEARCH" and "CANCEL"..  The image shows a dark blue background with a white rectangular box containing the text "(Search field)1-35 characters." Below the box, there are two buttons: one labeled "SEARCH" in green and the other labeled "CANCEL" in red. The text "Build 1-B002" is displayed at the bottom of the image.

A brown box with a white label displays "SEARCH (Search field) 1-15 characters" and two buttons: "SEARCH" and "CANCEL"..  The image shows a button with two options: "SEARCH" and "CANCEL." The button is labeled as "Build 1-B001." The text above the button states "(Search field)1-15 characters." The button has a brown background, and the text is black.

A light blue square divided into four quadrants, labeled "Build 1-B001", "Module A", "Module B", and "Module C", with arrows indicating build, impact areas, and modification in B002..  The image shows a square-shaped structure with four distinct modules labeled A, B, C, and D. Each module is represented by a white square with a black rectangle in the center. The modules are arranged in a grid-like pattern, with Module A positioned in the top left corner, Module B in the top right corner, Module C in the bottom left corner, and Module D in the bottom right corner.

There are also annotations in the image. The top left corner indicates "Build 1-B001," suggesting the modules are being built or assembled. The top right corner shows "Modification in B002," indicating modifications or updates to the modules. The bottom left corner shows "Impact Areas," indicating the areas where modifications are being made or considered. The bottom right corner shows "Modification in B002," indicating modifications or updates to the modules in B002.

A pie chart illustrates the impact of a new feature, with 70% of users not affected, 20% experiencing minor issues, and 20% reporting significant problems..  The image presents a circular diagram divided into three concentric circles, each representing a different level of impact analysis. The outermost circle is labeled "New Feature," the middle circle is labeled "Impact Analysis," and the innermost circle is labeled "Not Affected." The diagram highlights the percentage of users who experienced a specific impact, with the New Feature circle representing 20% of users, the Impact Analysis circle representing 70% of users, and the Not Affected circle representing the remaining 30% of users.

A blue box labeled "Test Strategy" is connected to an orange box labeled "Test Plan" via a plus sign, with a question about test logistics..  The image contains three key visual elements: a blue box labeled "Test Strategy," a blue box labeled "Test Logistics," and an orange box labeled "Test Plan." The blue box is labeled "Test Strategy" and the orange box is labeled "Test Plan." The blue box contains the text "Test Strategy is Approach i.e. What, Why, When & How in Testing," while the orange box contains the text "Test Logistics - Who in Testing?"

A blue flowchart illustrates the process of designing a product, starting with analyzing the product, followed by planning, resource planning, defining test criteria, scheduling, estimation, and determining test deliverables..  The image displays a flowchart illustrating the process of planning a test environment. It shows eight steps, each represented by a blue box with a white border. The steps include: Analyze the product, Design Test Strategy, Define Test Objectives, Plan Test Environment, Resource Planning, Schedule & Estimation, Determine Test Deliverables. Arrows connect each step to the next, indicating the progression of the process.

Four blue boxes on a white background outline a step-by-step process: "Pick One Or More Product Ideas", "Select Metrics", "Send Survey", and "Analyze Results"..  The image contains four distinct steps, each represented by a blue box with a white outline. The steps are numbered 01, 02, 03, and 04. Each step has a title and a corresponding icon or diagram. Step 01 shows a chart with a checkmark, step 02 displays a bar graph, step 03 shows a paper airplane, and step 04 shows a magnifying glass.

A cyclical process of product development, from interview to review, is illustrated with a man reviewing a document in a meeting room..  The image shows a workflow process involving three stages: Interview, Review, and Perform. It depicts a cycle of interaction between a client, a designer, and a developer. The process starts with an interview with the client, followed by a review of the product and project documentation. The final stage involves performing the product walkthrough. The image is visually represented through a flowchart, illustrating the sequence of events and the roles involved in the process.

A blue and white flowchart illustrates the testing process, starting with "Testing Scope" and progressing through "Verify Types of Testing," "Problems and Challenges," and "Test Logistics.".  The image presents a step-by-step process of testing a product or service. The steps are numbered 01, 02, 03, and 04. Each step is represented by a circle, and the text within the circles describes the specific testing phase.

Step 1: Testing Scope
Step 2: Verify Types of Testing
Step 3: Problems and Challenges
Step 4: Test Logistics

A software testing process flowchart outlines steps for defining and executing test cases, with a decision point to determine suspension criteria..  The image shows a flowchart with a process to define and execute a suspension criteria. The flowchart has three main steps: Define suspension criteria, Execute Test cases, Suspension criteria met?, Suspend the testing, and Developer fix the fail cases? The flowchart is divided into three sections: "Define suspension criteria," "Execute Test cases," and "Suspension criteria met?". The flowchart highlights the decision-making process for testing suspension criteria.

A man in a suit and a woman in a beige sweater discuss exit criteria in a meeting room, with a speech bubble indicating 90% total test cases..  The image shows a man, a woman, and a man in a business setting, sitting around a table. They appear to be discussing exit criteria for a test. The man is speaking to the woman, and a speech bubble is present above them. The speech bubble contains text that states, "Do you confirm the Exit Criteria?" The man in the blue shirt is looking at a laptop, and the woman is looking at him. The man in the suit is looking at the laptop screen. The overall scene suggests a business meeting or discussion about exit criteria for a test.

A four-panel infographic illustrates the importance of resource planning, resource allocation, and resource forecasting, highlighting 48% of projects will not be finished on time and 43% of projects will exceed allocated budget..  The image contains four distinct sections, each focusing on different aspects of resource planning. The sections are titled "Importance of Resource Planning," "How To Create Your Resource Plan?" "Without Resource Planning," and "Resource Planning Techniques." Each section includes a list of key visual elements, such as charts, icons, and diagrams, to illustrate the concept being discussed.

A blue project manager, orange build manager, and blue test manager collaborate on a software project, with the build server, database server, and test server in blue, and the build manager in orange..  The image displays a flowchart illustrating the process of building a database server. It shows a sequence of steps, including Project Manager, Build Server, Test Server, Build Manager, Database Server, and Test Manager. Each step is represented by a separate box, and arrows connect them to show the flow of the process. The flowchart highlights the steps involved in setting up the database server, including notification to setup the test release, setup on test instance through build scripts, and setup on test current release.

A diagram illustrates a web server for Guru99 Banking Site, connecting four web browsers to a central Internet server, with a cloud-shaped Internet connection point..  The image shows a diagram of a web server setup for a banking site, specifically for Guru99. The diagram includes a cloud labeled "Internet," which connects to four web browsers. The web servers are represented by two computer towers, one labeled "Database server" and the other "Web server for Guru99 Banking Site." The four web browsers are connected to the Internet cloud via the web servers, with each browser represented by a computer tower. The diagram also includes icons of a computer monitor, keyboard, and mouse, as well as a globe representing the world.

A project timeline for "Making Test Specification" shows milestones from August 1st to August 15th, with a performance test execution deadline on August 10th..  The image displays a project timeline with milestones, task names, start and end dates, and progress tracking. It includes a Gantt chart with task names, milestones, start and end dates, and project duration. The chart highlights the completion of the "Making Test Specification" milestone on August 4th, 2023, and the "Test Delivery" milestone on August 18th, 2023.

A flowchart illustrates the process of test case design techniques, including BVA, Equivalence Class Partitioning, Decision Table, State Transition, and Error Guessing..  The image contains a flowchart illustrating the test case design techniques. It has five distinct sections: Boundary Value Analysis (BVA), Equivalence Class Partitioning, Decision Table, State Transition, and Error Guessing. The BVA section is highlighted in blue, indicating its importance in the test case design process. The flowchart visually represents the sequential steps involved in designing and testing software, emphasizing the importance of BVA in ensuring the correctness and reliability of the software.
A plain white background with a subtle texture..  The image is entirely white with no visible visual elements, text, or diagrams.

A to five steps outline a process for analyzing and designing test cases, including identifying test scenarios, designing test cases, creating test data, creating test data, and mapping test cases to requirements..  The image displays a step-by-step guide on how to analyze and design test cases. It includes five numbered steps: 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. Each step provides a clear description of the process, including the purpose of identifying test scenarios, designing test cases, creating test data, and mapping test cases to requirements. The steps are presented in a linear fashion, with each step separated by a purple bar. The steps are visually distinct, with each step having a unique color and a corresponding number.

A flowchart illustrates a test scenario, with three test cases (Test Document, Test Scenario, Test Case) and their outcomes (Test Case Passed, Test Case Failed) connected by arrows..  The image displays a flowchart with three test scenarios. Each scenario is represented by a separate speech bubble, with the first scenario on the left, the second scenario in the middle, and the third scenario on the right. The test scenarios are labeled as "Test Document," "Test Scenario," and "Test Case."
